item.title: Bungie Addresses Marathon UI Gripes and PvP Concerns
item.content:encoded:
Bungie has posted a feedback sheet regarding the Marathon server slam, and surprisingly, it addresses almost every major gripe players have with the fledgling extraction shooter. Marathon has hit a tentative period following the access all areas server slam, which has left many players firmly on one side of the fence or the other.

The full game comes out next week, but Bungie has been quick to address key concerns right now based on feedback received from the server slam. That includes worries around the game’s overly complex UI and the lack of PvP-based clashes.

Bungie Recognizes PvP Woes in Marathon

In an article posted to social media, Bungie acknowledges six core issues with Marathon:

  • UI Feedback
  • PC Performance
  • PvP Frequency
  • Movement and Heat Generation
  • Med and Ammo Economy
  • Weasel Error Codes

When Marathon’s server slam opened, one of the more immediate concerns from players was around the game’s UI (User Interface), which is drastically complex. It’s a nightmare to understand right out of the gate, presenting a critical issue with onboarding. The team at Bungie said:

We are continuing to gather your posts and will keep iterating post‑launch (which, we’ll keep you posted on with regard to any future timelines once they’re available). Add your thoughts in the UI thread on our Discord so we can track them all in one place.

Another major worry was around the cadence of PvP clashes. Most players reported going an entire raid without even seeing other players, which is far from ideal for a PvPvE extraction game. It’s not at all like competing titles such as Escape from Tarkov and ARC Raiders, in which player-vs-player clashes are almost guaranteed.

The team wrote:

As we continue to keep an ear to the ground on this one, we’re further investigating total player density on non-beginner maps to cover all of our bases. If you’ve got any feedback – be it on Perimeter (Beginner), Perimeter, or Dire Marsh – we want to hear it!

In the first update post-launch, the team said that the player count on the game’s earliest maps had been boosted to promote more combat between players.

Movement and ‘heat generation’ have also been named as tricky areas. In Marathon, ‘heat’ replaces stamina, and the more aggressively you move, the faster you burn out and hit a wall. Many have reported that this happens far too quickly and the ramifications are far too impactful, and Bungie is investigating improvements.

Also, the lack of medical and ammo-based loot has been a gripe with players. It seems impossible to find meaningful amounts of ammunition around the map, and that’s a clear issue in a game with bullet-sponge AI enemies.

The Marathon server slam finishes tomorrow, March 2, and the full game hits the market on March 5. Do you think enough changes will be made to make it feel like a ‘better game’ at launch?

item.title: Netflix is Disappearing From The PlayStation 3 Platform Tomorrow
item.content:encoded:
It was around a month ago that retro gaming fans (kind of) were hit with a major revelation. Netflix, the titan streaming service, announced that it would cease operating an application on the PlayStation 3 platform. The console, which dropped twenty years ago, will no longer facilitate a working Netflix app from tomorrow, March 2.

It’s a wonder the application has lasted this long. For the last few weeks, users booting their dusty old PlayStation 3 consoles and loading Netflix would have been met with a message warning them of the application’s impending fate.

Another Nail in the PS3 Coffin

In February, PlayStation 3 users took to social media to discuss the removal of Netflix from their 20-year-old console platform. For some, it marked the end of an era, but for others, it was a total surprise that the application still worked… Barely.

One user explained:

But was still super slow, quality less good as it took more time to reach the 1080p

And, the worse, often froze at 10 minutes before end on movies 

The biggest concern amongst retro fans is that this was one of the sole remaining ways to consume 4:3 content on Netflix. Those seeking a blast from the past could plug their PS3 into a CRT TV and go wild streaming content from the old days.

Another user wrote:

2006-2026 o7 One less streaming service on a great multimedia platform

A third mourned the loss:

Dog I JUST mentioned Netflix for the ps3 earlier today. This is tragic.

If you loaded Netflix on a PlayStation 3 console in the last month, you’d have seen the message:

Unfortunately, Netflix will no longer be available on this device after March 2, 2026.

It’s time to move on, as impressive as it is that the app managed to cling to life this long. It was a similar situation when the Wii Shop closed down in 2019, forcing the removal of the Netflix app from that platform, which also facilitated cleaner 4:3 streaming.

Are you sad to see the back of Netflix on PlayStation 3? Let us know your retro woes on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Major Call of Duty Brand Shut Down After MLB Legal Clash
item.content:encoded:
In case you were wondering, the ‘World Series of Warzone’ moniker will never be seen again in an official setting. This is because, earlier this week, Activision suddenly dropped the name and trademark after a brief legal clash against Major League Baseball.

The spat came around the naming convention ‘World Series’, which the baseball folks determined was theirs and theirs alone, as a result of their lengthy history with competitions like the World Series, College World Series, and World Series 200. Activision relented and dropped the World Series of Warzone in the blink of an eye.

World Series of Warzone is No More

The World Series of Warzone was running for several years before being dropped by Activision. It was the biggest and most valuable tournament ecosystem in the Warzone space, accommodating thousands of battle royale fans every year. It was already confirmed that it wouldn’t be a thing this year, with Activision introducing things like the Warzone Resurgence Series instead.

Thanks to a scoop from Stephen Totilo at Game File, we now know why.

On Monday, the Office of the Commissioner of Baseball (aka the leadership team that runs MLB) officially filed a notice with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to oppose Activision’s long-running attempt to trademark the term “World Series of Warzone.”

That same day, Activision gave up, filing an express notice to the USPTO that it would abandon the trademark.

To avoid any confusion, the folks at Major League Baseball opposed the legitimization of the World Series of Warzone via the trademark office. But it didn’t end there.

The commissioner of the MLB also has an issue with the use of the term ‘zone’ in ‘Warzone‘, given the connotations it has with baseball and how the term surfaces in many ways in the sport.

It’s extremely unlikely they’ll get anyone to budge on that front. It’s like the Fine Brothers trying to trademark ‘React’ to stop YouTube creators aping their grind.

item.content:encoded:
Welcome to March! This coming week is really special, because it will mark the arrival of the 1000th NYT Connections puzzle! If you’re waiting for that all-important day to arrive, make sure you check back here every day to smash your NYT Connections puzzles with the best tips and hints around.

For today, we’ve got a doozy of a challenge. It’s a perfect way to get your brain whirring on a sleepy Sunday morning. Below, I’ve got today’s NYT Connections answers just waiting for you.

How to Play NYT Connections

In June 2023, NYT Connections emerged as yet another game in the ever-growing lineup of the New York Times titles. This title soared immediately, and it’s easy to see why. As a free-to-play, accessible New York Times game, NYT Connections is available worldwide and can be played on desktop devices or in a mobile app.

But how do you play NYT Connections?

The NYT team will provide you with a grid of 16 words once a day. The only task left up to you is to sort those words into four groups of four by finding their commonalities. Every NYT Connections puzzle has just one solution, and some words can have double meanings, so it can sometimes be tricky to figure out the answers.

It’s also important to stress that the words are color-coded: yellow, blue, green, and purple. That’s in order of difficulty, from least to most.

What’s critical here is that you get four guesses every day, and if you use those, your NYT Connections answers for today will be out of reach, as it’ll be game over.

item.title: GTA 6 Pre-Orders and Price Could Surface Soon Based on New PlayStation Data
item.content:encoded:
Grand Theft Auto 6 is, as we still know, coming out in November 2026. This has been reiterated numerous times by Take-Two and Rockstar Games since the original release date was pushed back for the second time. It has been a painful wait, but as far as we know, we’re getting ever closer… For now.

Recently, it was noted that a fresh wave of Grand Theft Auto 6 ‘title IDs’ was added to the PlayStation database, which could indicate that pre-orders are about to start rolling.

GTA 6 Could Be Priced Up Soon

In a post on social media, PlayStation Game Size revealed that GTA 6 title IDs have surfaced in the PlayStation back-end. This is usually one of the last steps before pre-orders open up for a game, but there’s no hard and fast rule as to how long it takes between the IDs being listed and the prices and pre-order packages being confirmed.

But this puts us one step closer to knowing how much GTA 6 will cost and what the pre-order bonuses for the game will be.

Recently, a digital storefront listed GTA 6 with a placeholder price of as much as $120, prompting concern from fans worldwide. We still have no idea how much Rockstar Games’ latest open-world epic will cost, and it’s a wildfire point of contention.

PlayStation Game Size addressed in a comment how long it might be before we see pre-orders go live:

To be honest, it completely depends on the publisher, and it’s not something I know for sure.

But I don’t think there’s going to be a long wait.

GTA 6 pre-order listings would represent a critical last step before a concrete launch. As they’d be digital, they’d reveal the game’s final price point, as well as what users receive for pre-ordering the game. It’ll be in-game items of some kind, but at this point, the bonuses are 100% based on conjecture.

Will you pre-order GTA 6 as soon as the listing becomes available? Let us know what you’re planning on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Today’s Wordle #1716: Hints and Answer for March 1, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Wordle challenges players to guess a fresh five-letter word each day in six tries or fewer. Whether you’re a beginner or a daily player, today’s tips and strategies can help you solve it faster and maintain your streak—if you’re open to a little extra help. So, if you’ve found yourself stuck with today’s Wordle, don’t worry, below you’ll find some helpful hints and even the answer for Wordle Game #1716 for March 1, 2026

To play today’s Wordle, head to the game’s website. If you want to go right to today’s answer without any tips or tricks, you can click right here.

IMPORTANT: The following information includes spoilers on today’s and yesterday’s editions of Wordle. If you don’t want the answer given to you, stop scrolling.

How To Play Wordle

Wordle is a simple but addictive word puzzle. Each day, players have to guess a five-letter word answer in no more than six attempts. After each guess:

  • Green letters are correct and in the right position.
  • Yellow letters are correct, but in the wrong position.
  • Gray letters are not in the word at all.

The goal is to guess the word in as few tries as possible. Daily puzzles keep players coming back for more, making it a fun brain exercise and a popular online trend.

Wordle can only be played on the New York Times website. There is currently no app for you to download the official game.

Wordle Hints For Today, March 1, 2026

The Wordle answer for game #1716 isn’t too rough a puzzle. According to the NY Times Wordle review, today’s answer takes an average of 4.3 out of 6 guesses. That makes it a full guess easier than the 5.3-guess average from February 28.

General Wordle Hints For March 1

Without giving today’s Wordle answer completely away, here are a few helpful hints for today to get you started:

  • Hint 1: This word is often used to describe something unexpected.
  • Hint 2: It usually refers to an outcome rather than an intention.
  • Hint 3: The situation it describes is typically rare, not routine.
  • Hint 4: You’ll often see it used when explaining why something succeeded without planning.

Use these clues to narrow down your guesses and increase your chances of solving Wordle #1716 for March 1, 2026.

Starter Words For March 1, 2026

If you want help getting started without having today’s Wordle answer given to you, there are a few starter words worth trying that will help you figure out some included letters. A few starter words that may help are:

  • LUCKY
  • FLUID
  • FLESH
  • BULKY

Today’s Wordle Answer For Game #1716 On March 1, 2026

If you’ve tried everything, including using the above hints, and are still stuck, you can find the answer to today’s Wordle below.

Answer: FLUKE

If you solved today’s Wordle without our answer, congratulations! If not, take note of the best tips above for tomorrow’s puzzle, and check back daily for more hints.

What Does Today’s Wordle Answer Mean?

FLUKE is a noun that has multiple meanings. It can mean “the part of an anchor that catches in the ground, especially the flat triangular piece at the end of each arm.” In other instances, Fluke means “an accidental advantage; stroke of good luck.”

Yesterday’s Wordle Answer

If you missed the previous game, here’s yesterday’s Wordle answer for Game #1715 on February 28, 2026

Answer: HYDRA

While not always the case, looking at previous words can sometimes give you insight into common patterns or letter usage in Wordle puzzles.

When Is The Next Wordle Game After #1716?

Wordle games are updated daily at 12 am or Midnight in your respective time zone. Information about the next game is often available in the hours before to give players a heads up. The game on March 2 will be Wordle Game #1717.

What Is Wordle?

Wordle is a daily word puzzle created by Josh Wardle. Initially developed as a prototype in 2013, it wasn’t fully released until 2021. The game challenges players to guess a five-letter word in six tries or fewer, using hints from each attempt to narrow down the answer. Its straightforward concept, accessibility, and the thrill of solving a new puzzle each day helped it surge in popularity by late 2021. The success of Wordle inspired numerous spin-offs and social media challenges, leading to its acquisition by The New York Times in early 2022.
